snippet.textDisplay: This is definitely the best visualisation of COVID-19. However, why is everyone trying to differentiate COVID-19 deaths from normal deaths when calculating its mortality rate? Why not simply measure the deviation from the normal mortality rate? This can be broken down per country, region, and city. The deviation from the norm then gives a much more reliable figure of the true mortality rate of COVID-19.
snippet.textOriginal: This is definitely the best visualisation of COVID-19. However, why is everyone trying to differentiate COVID-19 deaths from normal deaths when calculating its mortality rate? Why not simply measure the deviation from the normal mortality rate? This can be broken down per country, region, and city. The deviation from the norm then gives a much more reliable figure of the true mortality rate of COVID-19.

snippet.textDisplay: I'd take China's figures with a pinch of salt. The world knows that it was their initial cover-up that allowed this disease to spread so far in the first place, and so to pre-empt any attempt by foreign governments to seek compensation from China over the damage caused to their economies by its negligence, the Chinese Communist party is claiming (falsely) that all domestic infections have now been stamped out and that the only new cases are people being infected by foreigners coming back into China (thus China can counter-argue that other countries are damaging it by not getting their own infections under control as effectively as it has).
snippet.textOriginal: I'd take China's figures with a pinch of salt. The world knows that it was their initial cover-up that allowed this disease to spread so far in the first place, and so to pre-empt any attempt by foreign governments to seek compensation from China over the damage caused to their economies by its negligence, the Chinese Communist party is claiming (falsely) that all domestic infections have now been stamped out and that the only new cases are people being infected by foreigners coming back into China (thus China can counter-argue that other countries are damaging it by not getting their own infections under control as effectively as it has).

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, this was a nice try, and in a clean environment might actually have some accuracy, but your base data is HEAVILY flawed by false information, flawed collection practices and a lack of allowance for the source. Let's just look at one specific item among the really, really bad: China. The number of reported infections and deaths in China have fallen considerably. Unfortunately China is lying. HEAVILY! They mis-report infections -- if anyone is checked at all -- and they are hiding a LARGE number of dead people. One indicator of this is the cell phone usage and accounts in various areas of the country have been cancelled or the phone users have simply stopped.
These are people confined to their homes who have suddenly stopped using their phones. -- Hint, hint.
And don't even get me started on Italy!
All of which in turn means your models, predictions and conclusions are so false that the video is worthless.
Oh, one more thing: It Is A Flu!!!! If you want a successful model, base your estimates on all past FLU models. The hysteria around this is stupid. The Climate Change people FINALLY succeeded in making people afraid of shadows and "What If"s.
So mark this video as "cooking spoiled meat" and don't consume it. if you do, you'll get sick. LOLOLOLOLOL.

They mis-report infections -- if anyone is checked at all -- and they are hiding a LARGE number of dead people.  One indicator of this is the cell phone usage and accounts in various areas of the country have been cancelled or the phone users have simply stopped.
These are people confined to their homes who have suddenly stopped using their phones.  -- Hint, hint.

I found this medical practitioners suggestion very interesting and maybe it does care whether it is March or April, and temperature may have a lot to do with it.
15 April 2003

Chan Kam Ping

medical practioner

Hong Kong


Coronavirus may be killed by a higher body temperature

May I postulate this deadly virus has the following characteristics :



1. It is highly infectious because it infects by air-borne.



2. If the body temperature is below 36C, it grows very fast.



3. The destructive immune reaction will take some time (? 7-10 days) to

develop. Patients then start to have high fever.



4. During this period, if the body temperature is above 36.5C, and better

still, above 37C, the virus is attenuated or killed. Body will develop a

milder immune response and recover.



5. Patients with high fever can kill the virus. That is why CDC advocates

some patients recovered without anti-viral therapy.



Supports of this hypothesis are :



1. The victims usually stay in a cold environment for a reasonable time

after being infected, eg. in ward, hotel, aeroplane cabins, air-

conditioned offices.



2. This year, the climate in HK and Canton is extraordinarily cold and

persistent.



3. The weather in Thailand, Vietnam and Malaysia is hot, so their

outbreaks are easily controlled. The air-conditioning in HK and Singapore

are too cool, so control is difficult. Canada ia again too cold, so the

outbreak is serious.



4. Children (especially under age of 8 years) in China are much less

affected because they have higher metabolic rate and they are more active

(eg. travel a long distance to school and many other physical activities).

Children in HK are very sedentary, their homes and schools are air-

conditioned. Therefore the infection incidence of children are same as

adults in HK.



5. Elderly and people with chronic illness have lower BMR. They have

higher incidence rate and mortality.



6. Coronavirus can be found in cats, dogs, pigeons, ducks and geese. They

are not infected because all of them have very high BMR.



7. It is well known that herbal medicine can increase the metabolic rate

and kill the virus. The herbs prescribed in Canton are commented by WHO to

be effective.



8. Passengers from an infected aeroplane cabin have a greater chance to

cause an outbreak in a cold place,



9. Pregnant women are much less infected. They have high BMR. Are those

500 contact pregnant women free from infection?



10. More data are required to analyse if active people (eg. outdoor

workers, labourers) are less prone to be infected.



Therefore, I would like to suggest a simple test to confirm this

hypothesis :

Incubate the virus at different temperature in human tissue media, say

below 36C, 36.5C, 37C, and above 37C.



If the hypothesis is correct, then control is straight forward :



1. Put on more clothes to make body really warm,



2. maintain room temperature at least above 23C,



3. do exercise for 30 minutes daily, make sure you really sweat.



Let me tell you a legend happened in HK over a hundred years ago.

HK was infected by an unknown epidemic. In frustration, people (including

the sick) came to the street and watched the "Fire Dragon" dance. As a

miracle or due to the intense heat, many sick recovered and the epidemic

disappeared.


37°C is the standard temperature of the human body.



However, recent analyses and surveys suggest that the average body temperature is now lower.



For instance, a study of more than 35,000 people in the United Kingdom and nearly 250,000 temperature measurements found that 36.6°C is the average oral temperature.

snippet.textDisplay: Excellent way to plot the data.. The only improvement would be to use cases /million people since small countries will accumulate at the bottom when not corrected for population. In addition, when accounting for population, countries that do "BAD" will end up higher on the line.. So there is some extra information to be gained there..

snippet.textDisplay:
I think your Analysis is somewhat flawed based on the point that in most countries (well, mostly im speaking for the european ones) lowering the infection-rate is not the main goal(at the moment as we dont have potent visustatika yet so this is not achievable without a complete quarantine instead of a partial one which is currentliy not in place and which would have serious repercussions to the ability of the countries to keep neccessary services running). I am a Medicine Student myself in Germany and we fully expect the virus to have its projected High point of the Infection Rate in september. After this point the Infection Rate is expected to go down based on historic Data collected from earlier pandemics and Population studies, because many people will have developed asymptomatic (partial) immunity or had the symptoms alredy so the infection chain is interrupted. The main goal is to keep the Infection rate relatively low which on our Graph is correctly displayed as Growth, but without this Context it could be interpretet as Failure of containing this Health crisis. In reality the Quarantine is working better than you would read from the graph, because we are able to keep the infection rate low enough to not overencumber our intensive care Units for the seroius cases. So more important is the infected to dead and infected to recovered ratio imo.
Also a side note to the situation in China: They did many things right that many other countries failed to do like acting very quick and strict, but those numbers are always to be taken with caution referring to the last SARS corona situation and their information handling then. (but well those are the best numbers avaiable, seeing you took them from the JH university)


TLDR the main factor of how succesful the crisis management is that should be analyzed is the number of covid related deaths in each country and not neccesarily if there are new infections or not.
(i saw that its included in the interactive graph but your video focuses more o the infection rate, so i just wanted to point that out that this is a more powerful indicator)


some more very informative graphs and numbers:
https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/478220a4c454480e823b17327b2bf1d4 (numbers germany: Robert Koch Institute)
https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/685d0ace521648f8a5beeeee1b9125cd (numbers worldwide: WHO)
https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6 (numbers worldwide: John Hopkins University (slightly more up to date than WHO))

snippet.textDisplay: I have two issues here. The first is the claim that we don't understand exponential growth. I do. So who are you referring to ? Leave outside of this discussion some country leaders and medical leaders and the WHO because there will always be some who cannot understand anything.  Secondly the graph early on about how China has plateaued with confirmed cases. It is now generally accepted that China's figures are totally fictitious and probably out by at least a factor of 10. So it is totally bogus to include any figures from them. And any chart or table should not be built around use of the word "confirmed'. Any figures from around the world now are so misleading as to be ludicrous since most countries cannot claim 'confirmed' when we know that most countries have absolutely no idea of their real situation.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't know why they bothered including China. They have been lying from day one of this pandemic, and I doubt that anywhere close to their one-billion-person population has been tested. And given that after dishonest China, and India, who can't afford plumbing for their people, let alone Coronavirus tests, the USA has the largest population in the world, it isn't exactly fair to compare them to European countries that have less than 30% their population, without including some sort of per capita control. Everyone in England could get infected, and they would still look better than a USA where only 20% of the population was infected, so this graph isn't really helpful for determining which countries are fairing best, and thus which strategies for containing Coronavirus should be implemented by less successful countries.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't know why they bothered including China. They have been lying from day one of this pandemic, and I doubt that anywhere close to their one-billion-person population has been tested. And given that after dishonest China, and India, who can't afford plumbing for their people, let alone Coronavirus tests, the USA has the largest population in the world, it isn't exactly fair to compare them to European countries that have less than 30% their population, without including some sort of per capita control. Everyone in England could get infected, and they would still look better than a USA where only 20% of the population was infected, so this graph isn't really helpful for determining which countries are fairing best, and thus which strategies for containing Coronavirus should be implemented by less successful countries.

snippet.textDisplay: Graphs and charts are only good when the information being pumped into them is good. When you have countries that have cut back or limit case reporting, you run the risk of making it look like things are better when they perhaps aren’t, hence, China.

snippet.textDisplay: How to Tell If We Beating? Show the percentage of positive tests versus number of cases tested for that day. If you want to take it further, what percent of positive tests require serious care? Then what percent of those serious care cases lead to death.
